indicators.justification:
This research answered this indicator using data from the National Institute of Ecology and Climate Change (INECC). According to the General Law of Climate change, INECC is a decentralized federal institution that can coordinate or generate studies on climate change and evaluate adaptation and mitigation goals (1).
INECC has published data about emissions in the national Open Data Platform. The last dataset available on this website is from 2018 although, according to the metadata, information was last modified on 2020-10-30 (2). The latter dataset was used to answer the "Data Openness, timing, and structure" section.
Confidence was diminished to 95% because it is not clear if the information is timely and updated or not. According to the General Law of Climate Change (3), the inventory updates fossil fuel burning emissions annually and the rest of the emissions every two or four years. However, the last dataset available is for 2018.

Sources:
(1) General Law of Climate Change, article 13 and article 15, fractions I and VI. 2012. http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/LGCC_061120.pdf
(2) https://datos.gob.mx/busca/dataset/inventario-nacional-de-emisiones-de-gases-y-compuestos-de-efecto-invernadero-inegycei
(3) General Law of Climate Change, article 74. 2012. http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/LGCC_061120.pdf

indicators.justification:
The National Commission for the Use and Knowledge of Biodiversity (CONABIO) manages the National System about Mexican Biodiversity (SNIB), which has information about different species from the animal, fungi, plant, procaryote, and protist kingdoms.  The General Law of Ecologic Equilibrium and Environment Protection mandates the establishment of this information system (1).
The SNIB takes information from projects donated or financed by them. The information is transformed into a common structure and stored in a data warehouse where it is cleaned, standardized, and completed (2). After that process, CONABIO publishes on different web pages such as Mexico's open data platform, the Global Biodiversity Information Facility, and "Enciclovida."
The data used to answer the "Data openness, timing, and structure" section comes from the species catalog download option at the SNIB website (3). This option allows to download a bulk dataset or to request online information by taxonomic category. Information is free, but it asks for an e-mail to send the download link. The downside of this data is that there is no date of the last update, historical records, or clear license statement.
SNIB has an option to download data by the specimen (4). This option has a date of update, some previous records, and specifies available licenses for each specimen example. However, this dataset was not used since it doesn't contain variables about endangered species, even though endangered categories are a filter to download the data.
Mexico's open data platform was not used since there are multiples and diverse datasets. For example, a search as "species catalog" returns over 84 datasets from different projects and locations of Mexico. A search as "endangered species" returns up to 67 datasets. Therefore, the SNIB's download option by species was selected since it allows finding information for different species using the same data structure and with the required variables.

Sources:
(1) General Law of Ecologic Equilibrium and Environment Protection, article 80, fraction V. 1988.  http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/148_180121.pdf
(2) https://www.snib.mx/ejemplares/proceso
(3) https://www.snib.mx/taxonomia/descarga/
(4) https://www.snib.mx/ejemplares/descarga/

indicators.justification:
The Open Data Portal has data from the National Institute of Ecology and Climate Change (INECC) (1). Within that section, there are several datasets in csv and shp formats related to the vulnerability of humans, economic activities, and environments to climate change. All datasets include gender gap variables,  and some also have variables about access to public services.
The National Center for Disaster Prevention has visualizations related to disaster risks such as COVID-19, volcano eruptions, earthquakes, and storms (2). The website has a dataset about emergency declaratory (3). 
This research answered the "Data openness, timing, and structure" section using the emergency declaratory dataset of the National Center for Disaster Prevention since it is more timely and updated than the INECC datasets. Besides, the file is available in a bulk download that has information since 2020.
The INECC datasets have variables related to public services accessibility and gender gap, but it isn't updated, it doesn't have historical records, and it doesn't have a bulk download.

Sources:
(1): https://datos.gob.mx/busca/organization/inecc
(2): http://www.atlasnacionalderiesgos.gob.mx/
(3): http://www.atlasnacionalderiesgos.gob.mx/apps/Declaratorias/#

indicators.justification:
Mexico became a member of the Beneficial Ownership Leadership Group and adopted the Transparency Disclosure Principles of Beneficial Ownership in 2019 (1).
The country has an Action Plan 2019-2021 where it commits to(2):
Prepare an Action Plan to implement the Transparency Disclosure Principles of Beneficial Ownership by August 2021.
Afterward, disclose open data of beneficial ownership in extractive industries.
Develop a national registry of beneficial ownership by 2023.
According to the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (3), Mexico has a roadmap to disclose beneficial ownership. In the last EITI report about Mexico (4), there still is no data. Looking at the EITI portal, the information wasn't found (5).
The PODER project was the only information found for Beneficial Ownership, and their data mainly comes from other countries.

Sources:
(1) Ministry of Public Administration, México se suma al Grupo de Liderazgo sobre transparencia de beneficiarios finales, December 9 2019, https://www.gob.mx/sfp/prensa/mexico-se-suma-al-grupo-de-liderazgo-sobre-transparencia-de-beneficiarios-finales?idiom=es

indicators.justification:
The National Directory of Economy Units (DENUE) is published by Mexico's National Statistics Agency (1). The Law of the National System of Statistics and Geographic Information ensures the DENUE existence since it requires a national company's directory (2).
The Mexican System of Company Information (SIEM) is ensured by the Law of Business Chambers and its Confederations. Companies that belong to a Chamber of services, commerce, tourism, or industry have to register in SIEM (3).
The DENUE was selected to answer all sub-questions since it covers all active companies in Mexico (4). Besides, DENUE complies with all of the "Data openness, timing, and structure" questions, while SIEM doesn't have downloads or any additional information.
The 2020 version of the data was used since the latest update is outside the scope of this study.

Sources:
(1) https://www.inegi.org.mx/
(2) Law of the National System of Statistics and Geographic Information, article 23. 2008. http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/LSNIEG_200521.pdf

(4) https://www.inegi.org.mx/temas/directorio/

indicators.justification:
Besides the federal government's Ministry of Health, the National Statistics agency publishes birth statistics (1) and mortality (2). The latter agency's data covers more years but presents data aggregated data such as "Men birth" (3) or "Women deaths" (4) by state and municipality, so it doesn't have the granularity required by the indicator.
The Ministry's of Health civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS) dataset was selected to answer elements of the indicator since it disaggregates data by birth and provides information about the mother. Regarding mortality, a 2019 dataset was used to answer elements in "Data fields and quality" since it was the latest available (5). This dataset has ICD causes of death, but the related element was answered as partial since the data dictionary doesn't state the standard version (6).
the 2020 CRVS dataset was used to answer the "Data openness, timing, and structure" section. According to the Open Data Platform, the last date of update of this dataset was 2021-06-09 (5), but another source from the Ministry of Health says that CRVS open data was last updated on 2020-11-23 (6), so this date was considered to justify its use. It was preferred over the Mortality dataset since it has a 2020 update.

indicators.justification:
The federal government has a COVID-19 website where it publishes information related to the pandemic. The portal has a section dedicated to health facilities' occupation with visualizations about the percent of beds, ventilators, and ICU beds occupied by the health facilities, municipalities, jurisdictions, and states. The portal also allows downloading information in machine-readable formats. Data is almost real-time, being delayed only by one day.
The Ministry of Health's website and Mexico's Open Data Portal don't have more real-time information than this website, so the "Data openness, timing, and structure" was answered using the ICU bed occupation CSV file, although all available downloads in the portal have the same characteristics.  Data from the General Direction of Epidiomology wasn't used (even though it has more variables and granularity) since it only has partial information about applied tests.
A downside of this portal is that information needs to be downloaded by day, and changing each date can be a slow and time-consuming process. However, independent journalists have consolidated datasets and made them publicly available for all people to download (1).
Sources:
(1) Serendipia, Datos abiertos de ocupación hospitalaria en México, April 15, 2021, https://serendipia.digital/covid-19/datos-abiertos-de-ocupacion-hospitalaria-en-mexico/

indicators.justification:
The federal government has a COVID-19 website where it publishes information related to the pandemic. The portal has a section dedicated to vaccination, although nothing is presented in open formats. The website does have a data section, but it has no information on vaccination.

The Ministry of Health's website and Mexico's Open Data Portal don't have more information on vaccination, so the "Data openness, timing, and structure" was answered using the vaccination section in the COVID-19 website (1). The Ministry of Health provided daily data on doses applied through press conferences. However, the information could only be seen in PowerPoint templates and, since March 2021, independent journalists pointed at information inconsistencies and the lack of open data (2).
The information used to answer this indicator comes from the federal government's covid-19 website. However, no data is available in open formats that allow a specific analysis of vaccines applied to different population groups. Government agencies denied information to independent journalists that tried to obtain the datasets through transparency requests. The Ministry of Health said that the information was inexistent even though they are leading de vaccine strategy while the Ministry of Defense answered that they weren't responsible for the data although they are implementing it (2).

Sources:
(1) http://vacunacovid.gob.mx/wordpress/
(2) Padilla, A., Serendipia, Salud aún no publica datos abiertos sobre la vacunación contra COVID-19; las cifras de la conferencia son inconsistentes, March 10, 2021, https://serendipia.digital/covid-19/datos-abiertos-vacunacion-covid-en-mexico/
(3) Velázquez, S., Roa, J., Padilla, A., and Alarid-Escudero, F., Animal Político, ¿Qué tan abiertos son los "datos abiertos" de vacunación en México?, June 23 2021, https://www.animalpolitico.com/el-contagio/que-tan-abiertos-son-los-datos-abiertos-de-vacunacion-en-mexico/#_ftn4

indicators.justification:
In Mexico, private land tenure is the responsibility of each local government. Currently, there is no national platform that consolidates data from all local governments. There is a national land tenure and use platform (1), although its public version never was finished, and there is no way to check its data (2). The federal Ministry of Territorial, Urban, Agrarian Development (SEDATU) is currently developing a national information system with maps and data, although by March 2021 it almost had a 50% progress (3).
Therefore, data on land use was looked for Mexico City, the highest populated city and state from all the country. The following two sources were found for land use:
The open geographic system from Mexico City has csv and shp files for every town in Mexico City. According to the metadata (4), the last modification was in June 2020, and its frequency is every six months, so the information is not updated.
Mexico City's open data portal has a bulk csv file with land use information for every town. The dataset was created on 2021-01-12, and its last update was on 2021-05-24.
The latter source was selected to answer all sub-questions of the indicator.

Sources:
(1) SEDATU, Crea la SEDATU Plataforma Nacional de Información Registral y Catastral, April 25 2017, https://www.gob.mx/sedatu/prensa/crea-la-sedatu-plataforma-nacional-de-informacion-registral-y-catastral
(2) https://datos.gob.mx/herramientas/plataforma-nacional-de-informacion-registral-y-catastral-pniryc
(3) Redacción, Alcaldes de México, la SEDATU presenta avances del Sistema de Informatción Territorial y Urbano, March 3 2021, https://www.alcaldesdemexico.com/notas-principales/la-sedatu-presenta-avances-del-sistema-de-informacion-territorial-y-urbano/
(4) https://sig.cdmx.gob.mx/documents/113/download

indicators.justification:
In Mexico, private land tenure is the responsibility of each local government. Currently, there is no national platform that consolidates data from all local governments. There is national land tenure and use platform (1), although its public version never was finished, and there is no way to check its data (2). The federal Ministry of Territorial, Urban, Agrarian Development (SEDATU) is currently developing a national information system with maps and data, although by March 2021 it almost had a 50% progress (3).
Therefore, this indicator was answered using data from the National Agrarian Registry (RAN), which has information on social land tenure in Mexico. This government agency's main function is to control social land tenure and to provide legal certainty  (4).
The dataset selected to answer the "Data openness, timing, and structure" section is available in shp and csv formats and contains information about certified social properties. Data has granular geographic information, the type of social tenure, and a property identifier. Data from the RAN website was preferred over the one available in the Open Data Platform since its last update was from 2019-12-31. The data from the RAN website's last update is from 2021-02-25.

indicators.justification:
Several datasets are available to answer sub-questions from this indicator, as can be seen in the "Kinds of data" sub-question. However, the budget spending dataset from the first quarter of 2021 was used to answer most of the "Data fields and quality" and the "Data openness, timing, and structure" sections. The reason is that this dataset covers all of the budget programs and classifications, has all of the federal government agencies, social security institutions, state-owned enterprises, some public corporations, and transfers to local governments. This dataset is regularly updated and has the necessary identifiers to connect with information regarding investment projects, performance indicators, and procurement processes.
Regarding the question about open official tools available to explore the data, the answer was "No" even when Mexico has the Open Fiscal Data Package on its budget transparency platform (1). The reason is that the viewer is updated until 2019 while the dataset has a 2021 update.
The Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability (PEFA) has not evaluated Mexico (2), so this research used normative documents that set classifications to see if they were based on international standards. The administrative classification is based on the Government Finance Statistics Manual (GFSM) 2011 and Mexico's system of national accounts (3). The economic classification also follows the GFSM and Mexico's system of National Accounts (4). The Functional Classification follows the Classification of Functions of Government, GFSM 2001, and Mexico's system of national accounts (5). The program classification doesn't mention if it follows any standard (6), but the sub-question was answered as "Yes" using the PEFA criteria, which states that the program classification may substitute for subfunctional classification it has a level of detail corresponding to the subfunctional classification (7).

Sources:
(1) https://www.transparenciapresupuestaria.gob.mx/es/PTP/datos_presupuestarios_abiertos
(2) https://development-data-hub-s3-public.s3.amazonaws.com/ddhfiles/94569/wb_fmis_obd_dataset.xlsx
(3) Acuerdo por el que se emite la clasificación administrativa, I. Introducción. 2011. https://www.conac.gob.mx/work/models/CONAC/normatividad/NOR_01_02_002.pdf
(4) Acuerdo por el que se emite la Clasificación Económica de los Ingresos, de los Gastos y del Financiamiento de los Entes Públicos, II. Concepto. 2011. https://www.conac.gob.mx/work/models/CONAC/normatividad/NOR_01_12_001.pdf
(5) Acuerdo por el que se emite la clasificación funcional del gasto, A. Aspectos Generales. 2010. https://www.conac.gob.mx/work/models/CONAC/normatividad/NOR_01_02_003.pdf
(6) Acuerdo por el que se emite la clasificación programática (Tipologia genera). 2013. https://www.conac.gob.mx/work/models/CONAC/normatividad/NOR_01_02_004.pdf
(7) PEFA. 2016. Framework for assessing public financial management. PEFA Secretariat. https://www.pefa.org/sites/pefa/files/news/files/PEFA-Framework_English.pdf

The National Digital Platform (1)has information of seven subnational governments that adhere to open data standardization: Aguacalientes, Jalisco, Guanajuato, Mexico State, Zacatecas, Tlaxcala and Quintana Roo.

indicators.justification:
Mexico has two sources for public procurement data:
The national e-procurement portal "Compranet."
The Open Procurement Portal in the Budget Transparency Platform.
The first of the sources is an electronic procurement system used by the central government, social security institutions, extra-budgetary funds, public corporations, and local governments. It has information on the tender, awards, and contract stages. The second source has information on the planning and the contract implementation stages (1).
The Ministry of Public Administration, the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit, and the Digital Strategy Coordination created the Open Procurement Portal in 2017. The objective was to have a single webpage that joined information for the whole procurement process (1). However, the platform doesn't update data regularly and consistently, contract implementation is up to date,  but tender and awards have not since 2020-01-23 (2). The platform has an open data section with bulk downloads, but links to download are broken or were published only in July 2021 (3).
Therefore, the contracts dataset of CompraNet (4) was chosen to answer the "Data openness, timing, and structure section." This dataset is regularly updated, covers a big amount of government agencies, and has information on the tender, award, and contract stages.

Sources
(1) https://www.transparenciapresupuestaria.gob.mx/work/models/PTP/programas/consulta/docs/PoliticaPublicacionEDCA-APF.pdf
(2) https://nptp.hacienda.gob.mx/contratacionesabiertas/home#!/
(3) https://datos.gob.mx/busca/organization/contrataciones-abiertas
(4) https://www.gob.mx/compranet/documentos/datos-abiertos-250375

indicators.justification:
While it is quite noticeable that the agenda has left the Office of the Presidency's mandate, which gave it high-level prevalence in the previous period, some specific Ministries have still made strides forward. So is the case of Data Mexico (1) which allows the integration, visualization, and analysis of public data to promote innovation, inclusion, and diversification of the Mexican economy.

Other highlightable initiatives in this regard are the ones coming from the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit (SHCP) through the Budget Transparency Portal (2) which has supports data use through initiatives such as the international open data day through the Data Rally (3) and the Exploratados for a better budget for sustainable development organized jointly with the CIEP (Center for Economic and Budgetary Research) achieving the involvement of international organizations such as the Global Initiative for Fiscal Transparency (GIFT, for its acronym in English (4), the CAF (Development Bank of America Latina) and the UNDP. This is an initiative that is just one amongst others in the context of the Open Data Day (5).

It is also important to mention the contests, particularly focused on children and youth audiences, carried out by the National Institute of Transparency, Access to Information and Protection of Personal Data (INAI) (6), which take place every year and are also reflected through of constant radio, television and social media campaigns.

The government does not encourage data reuse that contradicts his agenda. The government actively attacks journalistic efforts in its daily morning press conference by the President and also there has been a significant increase in violence against journalists and activists (7).

indicators.justification:
While it is quite noticeable that the agenda has left the Office of the Presidency's mandate, which gave it high level prevalence in the previous period, some specific Ministries have still made strides forward. So is the case of Data Mexico (1) which allows the integration, visualization and analysis of public data to promote innovation, inclusion and diversification of the Mexican economy. Also, there are several guidance documents that are still in place for the implementation of the Open Data Policy, such as the Implementation Guide of the Open Data Policy (2) and the Technical Standard for the Publication of Open Data of Statistical and Geographic Information of National Interest (3).
Unlike in previous years, it is not possible to assess the specific budget allocation for the Open Data Strategy, as it has been atomized in several state units, which have a plethora of other mandates, so is not possible to know, of their current budgets, how much do they allocate to their open data mandate.

responses.response_text: The open data initiative covers much of the national government, and there are similar initiatives in many sub-national areas.
responses.subquestion_text: How widely does this, or similar, open data initiatives apply?

indicators.justification:
Subnational governments have large heterogeneity of will and capacities, there are very advanced states such as the case of Jalisco (1) or Mexico City (2) that have a sustained initiative, and also there are, in the words of Pablo Villarreal, head of the unit of the National Digital Platform of the Executive Secretariat of the National Anticorruption System, other states with intermediate level initiatives such as Chihuahua and others with a basic level such as Oaxaca, which have the will but not yet the capacities or have not yet materialized versions of their efforts. Nonetheless, the Executive Secretariat is actively supporting 7 states in the opening of standardized databases for key topics.

Nonetheless, it is not possible to identify that there are efforts that involve all states. Even so, it is worth noting that there are initiatives led by the Federal government like the Open Data Rally / Datquests promoted by the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit through the Budget Transparency Portal (3) and the Global Initiative for Fiscal Transparency that in its 2021 edition also involved the governments of Mexico City and that of the State of Guanajuato.

It should also be noted that there are at least 10 specific portals for opening data in sub-national governments:
https://datos.cdmx.gob.mx/
http://datos.morelos.gob.mx/ 
https://datos.jalisco.gob.mx/ 
http://www.coahuilatodotransparente.gob.mx/ 
http://datos.edomex.gob.mx/ 
http://datosabiertos.sanpedro.gob.mx/pagesda/Default.aspx 
http://datostrc.gob.mx/ 
https://datosabiertos.pueblacapital.gob.mx/ 
http://datos.guadalajara.gob.mx/ 
http://www.datosabiertoszacatecas.org.mx/ 

And there are outstanding initiatives for the opening of specific information on open budget with the use of international data standards, by the states of Mexico City, Guanajuato, Michoacán, and Querétaro, among others. As well as in the matter of open contracting using the international standard in the matter, and the same happens with different specific thematic areas, so a will and capability increase are pretty noticeable, yet still to be materialized in many spaces.

responses.response_text: The examples given are exceptions: the majority of cities and regions do not have the capacity to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: How widespread are local capacities to effectively manage data?

indicators.justification:
There are different initiatives of the Mexican State from the permanent offer of the National Institute of Transparency, Access to Information and Protection of Personal Data (1) that has the generation of capacities at the regulatory level on government openness from the legal perspective, including open data and the protection of personal data; to more applied initiatives such as the National Public Policy Laboratory (2) of the Center for Economic Research and Teaching, a center of excellence of the National Council for Science and Technology, which offers generation of specific capacities in data mining and the creation of visualizations in its department of interdisciplinary studies (3).

In the same sense, the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit, through the Budget Transparency Portal and its specific section on Face-to-face and distance training (4) annually presents the Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) "How to understand the budget? Public spending through data ", which focuses on data analysis through basic capacities to understand the budget, in conjunction with Social Tic (5), a leading civil society organization in data activism in Mexico and Latin America.

Nonetheless, we were not able to identify systematic efforts of incorporating data matters in capacity building efforts from the Ministry of Public Administration, which has the mandate to provide capacity building for public civil servants. There was no single available course on their per-registration-only portal for capacity building offer per civil servants: Training System for Public Servants (6).

It is also important to note that even when it is not a centrally organized as a common strategy for all public servants, definitions of open data are part of the core contents of the capacity building plans from the National Institute of Transparency, Access to Information and Protection of Personal Data, which are mandatory for some public servants. Also, it is duly noted that there are several events hosted by government specific agencies, alongside international cooperation agencies and civil society to promote topics related to data literacy and data skills that are available for civil servants.

indicators.justification:
The "The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data." and the "Provisions for openness, timing, and structure" were answered "No" since Mexico has no national registry.
Mexico became a member of the Beneficial Ownership Leadership Group and adopted the Transparency Disclosure Principles of Beneficial Ownership in 2019 (1). The country has an Action Plan 2019-2021 where it commits to (2):
-Prepare an Action Plan to implement the Transparency Disclosure Principles of Beneficial Ownership by August 2021.
-Afterward, disclose open data of beneficial ownership in extractive industries.
-Develop a national registry of beneficial ownership by 2023.
According to the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (3), Mexico has a roadmap to disclose beneficial ownership. In the last EITI report about Mexico (4), there still is no data. Looking at the EITI portal, the information wasn't found (5).
The "The framework requires a verification process" sub-question was answered "Yes" since the law gives the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit the possibility to perform verification routines. However, according to Santiago Nieto, head of the Finance Intelligence Unit of the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit, there still are challenges to identify beneficial owners. Currently, the Federal law of prevention and identification of transactions involving resources derived from illicit sources reform hasn't been approved by Congress; the objective of this reform is that institutions can identify beneficial owners better in vulnerable activities. However, according to Santiago Nieto, the commerce regulation also needs to be reformed so commercial enterprises can inform the government about beneficial owners (6).

indicators.justification:
Mexico has an autonomous body responsible for the calculation of official statistics and the implementation of the census: the National Institute of Statistics and Geography (INEGI, for its acronym in Spanish) (1), which issues guidance for all levels of government and considers the best international practices. The foregoing includes a single data repository (2) that has machine-readable metadata, as well as standardized processes for the publication of datasets and for the management of their life cycle, including the storage of historical information, through specific committees by topic. The foregoing is established in its Internal Regulations (3).

INEGI's repository includes different human and machine-readable formats for each data set, basic viewers and downloads in different formats, including remote processing queries through its Microdata Laboratory (4). The repository in general includes a feedback mechanism through a "suggestion" box, as well as a chat that provides guidance through direct online conversation with a specialist.

Additionally, the Executive Branch has a centralizing page for the Federal Government's open data that continues to be active (5) and through the "Participate" initiative, it collects citizen opinions on existing or potential data sets, which has an open consultation process unrelated to datasets from June 2021 but does not show historical information on past consultations on open datasets (6). However, this site has not received updates in the last year that are visible through its page, so it is considered that currently, the most relevant source of information in open formats as a single repository is that of INEGI.

Despite this, in terms of processes, the initiative of the Executive Branch has a technical guide that frames the formats (7), the update cycles and the metadata (based on DCAT), but also the responsibilities, the processes of implementation and promotion of reuse (8). The data is kept in a centralized national repository of open data (based on CKAN). This process is supported by ADELA (9), a software developed by the government in conjunction with CodeandoMX (10) that allows agencies to publish their data sets and facilitates further monitoring of this process.
Nonetheless it is very important to note that the data management policy changed for all the Federal Government on the 30th of june of 2021 by the AGREEMENT by which the Transparency, Open Government and Open Data Policy of the Federal Public Administration 2021-2024 is issued (11) Therefore spamming out of the research period. This new management policy will definitely alter the responses for the Federal level in the coming editions.

indicators.justification:
There are two relevant laws regarding the protection of personal data: The General Law of Protection of Personal Data in Possession of Obliged Subjects (1) and the Federal Law on the Protection of Personal Data in Possession of Individuals (2). The combination of both apply to all the levels and branches of government. I would say the protection of personal data is extensive, as the relevant regulatory framework does not only promote the protection of the data and has been implemented in practice, but it complies with quality requirements such as providing the right of choice / consent of the people, the right to access and / or correct personal data, imposes clear responsibilities on those who guard the information (differentiating between the figuv  vc res of "charged with" and "responsible" for the data), and provides the right to redress against public and private bodies that violate data privacy.

Additionally, these regulations contemplate the procedures to anonymize before publication, which guarantees that sensitive and personally identifiable data are eliminated prior to any publication.

In fact, the right to the protection of personal data is only limited by exception provided in the aforementioned laws and is stipulated in the Political Constitution of the Mexican United States (3), in its article 16 as a fundamental right or individual guarantee that cannot be waived. Therefore, sanction mechanisms are provided for the infringement of personal data, ranging from warnings, to economic, civil and even criminal sanctions.

The autonomous body for the protection of personal data is the National Institute of Transparency, Access to Information and Protection of Personal Data (4), and constantly issues consultation material to facilitate understanding of the concept of personal data, disclose best practices on privacy and confidentiality notices and what to do if you consider a potential vulnerability of this right. These materials exist for both the private and public sectors and range from the best Guides of self-regulation schemes in the field of personal data protection to suggested minimum criteria for contracting computing services in the cloud that involve the processing of personal data.


## Sources

indicators.justification:
There are specific regulations that show the existence of a national open data policy with processes, responsibilities, and deadlines (1): General Law of Transparency and Access to Public Government Information, Decree Establishing the Regulation on Open Data, Implementation Guide for the Open Data Policy, Technical Standard for the Publication of Open Data of Statistical and Geographic Information of National Interest (2) and the Scheme for Interoperability and Open Data.

Additionally, there is the office of the Executive Secretariat of the National Anticorruption System, which has the mandate to implement the National Digital Platform (3), whose mission is explicitly to generate intelligence from the government's public open data and promote the standardization of key sets conforming with the Open Data Charter.

Also, Mexico has the National Institute of Transparency, Access to Information and Protection of Personal Data (4), which promotes, through the General Law of Transparency and Access to Public Information (5) the implementation of open data formats.

However, the opening of public information and specifically the frontal open data strategy has lost relevance in the public agenda in the current administration (2018-2024), which is verifiable, for starters through its elimination from the National Development Plan 2019-2024 (6) despite the fact that it did exist in the previous National Plan (7) and had a specific compliance/performance indicator, as well as specific implementation guidelines. Currently, no performance indicators are located regarding the opening of additional or proactive data sets, and there are not easily available progress reports available in this regard.

indicators.justification:
This indicator's framework includes laws related to the publication of budget, spending, income, debt, and non-financial indicators. However, the General Law of Government Accountability was preferred to answer element sub-questions from the "Provisions for definitions, kinds, and fields," the "Provisions for openness, timing, and structure," and the "Extent" sections since it covers the whole public sector (1). This law provides criteria about the minimum content and periodicity that the income law, proposed budget, in-year reports, and year-end reports should have. Other laws were used to specify additional spending, debt, or performance reports.
The Federal Law on Budget and Fiscal Responsibility was preferred to answer the "Provisions for data quality" since the General Law of Government Accountability only provides general criteria and barely specified responsible government institutions. The Federal Law on Budget and Fiscal Responsibility covers the federal government and state or local government reports when they spend federal resources. Specifics on this matter for state and local government would have to be looked at in each state's law.
To answer if open data is set out in binding policies, laws, or regulations, the keyword "open data" was searched in the whole framework. No results were found, except in the Budget Law from 2020. This law establishes that the Ministry of Finance has to publish open data for the proposed budget, the enacted budget, the quarterly spending reports, and the year-end report (2). However, this law is updated every year, and this article didn't appear in the 2021 budget, so it was answered that there only were requirements to publish data.
The Federal of Budget and Fiscal Responsibility, and the Genera Law of Budget Accountability, were used to answer the economic classification disaggregation level. The only specification found on this matter was in the federal law, which specifies that the enacted budget needs to have an annex with budget distribution by the administrative classification and the economic classification at the chapter and concept levels (3). These levels are the most aggregate ones (4). The General Law on Government Accountability only establishes that budget documents need to have an economic classification.

Sources:

indicators.justification:
Both the General Law of Political Parties (1) and the GENERAL LAW OF INSTITUTIONS AND ELECTORAL PROCEDURES (2) give the National Electoral Institute full authority to provide guidance in this regard for proper fiscalization and transparency purposes. It is also duly to note that specific data points to be collected are also mandated by the General Law of Transparency and Access to Public Government Information (3), as political parties are part of the obligated subjects under its Article 23. Nonetheless, the relevant electoral framework does not specify the information requirements and the formats.

It is duly to mention that there is a specific website for this regard from the National Electoral Institute (4) that provides useful information. Nonetheless, it only includes public financing, not information on private financing of political activities. It is also worth mentioning that the same institution publishes an open data website that includes information about fiscalization. (5).
Some information about in kind and private financial support can be found in broad numbers in the National Transparency Portal of the National Institute of Transparency, Access to Information and Protection of Personal Data as required by specific publication formats(6).

indicators.justification:
The General Law for Regulatory Improvement states throughout the requirement of "comments" of regulation projects and gives mandate over all its contents to the National Commission for Regulatory Improvement. Nonetheless, the Law does not state the need for the information on this topic to be publicly available using open formats. There is a mention on open data regarding "guidelines, bases, instruments, guidelines, and mechanisms aimed at
implementation of the policy of regulatory improvement" explicitly stated in articles 17 and 18 of the Law. Yet, it is not clear that this applies specifically to public consultations. It is interpreted that there is no specific guidance on this remark as the Regulatory Impact Manifestation Computer System, where comments on regulatory instruments are collected, does not provide information in open data.

There is another public participation mechanism, yet is not necessarily related to regulatory matters, even if it can be used for that, that is implemented by the federal government through the GUIDELINES for the promotion, conformation, organization, and operation of the mechanisms of citizen participation in the dependencies and entities of the Federal Public Administration (5). This information does possess open data format publications (4).

indicators.justification:
The General Law of Transparency and Access to Public Government Information (1) in its Article 45, fraction VIII. clearly states that it is a responsibility of Transparency Units to "Keep a record of requests for access to information, responses, results, costs
of reproduction and shipment". Nonetheless, the Law itself does not include a specific mandate for this information to be gathered in structured formats and then published in open data. Since the information is indeed published and in advanced open data formats, we assume there is an internal guide for this purpose. Said guide was not easily findable through the research.

indicators.justification:
Searching "Due diligence" in Google results mainly in fiscal and legal diligence on customers to ensure the safety of transactions. Services found relied on the use of expert teams, and there was no explicit information on the use of open data. The research found two data-driven services, but they use international data and are not tailored to Mexico, so they were not considered to answer this indicator. One of them is Refinitiv that has the World-Check database to search for politically exposed persons or high-risk companies and individuals. The database includes beneficial owners and has an API (1). However, this service wasn't included in the indicator since the database is international and was acquired by Refinitiv after merging with the Blackstone Group in 2018 (2). Another service that wasn't considered is LexisNexis Risk Solution, even though it is data-driven. Its data has an international focus, and it doesn't mention the use of open data, although the webpage says that its sources are open to verification (3).
"Know your customer" searches result more in client identity verification services. A relevant example is LatinID, an identity verification service that uses Mexican sources such as national Politically Exposed Person lists and citizen identity registries from the National Electoral Institute, the Ministry of Public Education, and the National Population Registry (4). However, this service wasn't included since it focuses on identity verification and doesn't seem to use open company directories.

Sources

(4) https://latinid.com.mx/id-biometric-system/

indicators.justification:
This research answered the indicator with sources that used the National Agrarian Registry or data from local government's property registry offices to create reports. 
The Mexican Civil Council for Sustainable Forestry (CCMSS) promotes that communities should manage the forests they inhabit. CMSS develops map visualizations to show ecosystems,  economic activities, or land tenure (1). These last maps use data from the National Agrarian Registry.
The selected media article talks about gender inequality in the agriculture sector (2). The article has an interview with a manager from Yara, a company dedicated to crop nutrition, and shows statistics about the participation of women in the agriculture sector. The article provides statistics about the proportion of women that are leaders of social property, using data from the National Agrarian Registry.
The private sector example (3) doesn't use land data to influence the interests of more equitable and inclusive land tenure and use. However, it provides land use data so users can get more information about properties' land use.
The academia was selected because it used the National Agrarian Registry to determine the number of surveys of an investigation (4). The research's objective was to show that social property favors forest ecosystems conservation.

indicators.justification:
The 5 topics are very different:
- Political finance information on the campaign and party finance
- Interest and asset declaration
- Lobby registry
- Public consultation on rulemaking
- Performance of right to information/ freedom of information processes
The information that has been more broadly used by Civil Society is that of Interest and asset declarations as civil society played a big role in the requirements for these declarations and the actual templates required. In that sense, the whole information on this data set is used.
Therefore there is no homogeneous coverage of the information. Nonetheless, it is possible to see that there are specific topics that bring about more interest from the public.
The information more broadly used by the media is that of political finance on the campaign and party finance, as well as that of the interest and assets declarations but it is not clear that the information used is open data. Also, there is no clear evidence of use of the information from the academic sector or the private sector, which would require further in-depth analysis into several academic repositories per topic.
 
Given the lack of interoperability and complexity and atomization of the information, the reason behind this situation is probably the poor quality and availability of information.
